brief_summary.textblock:
The primary purpose of this study is to assess safety and efficacy of the Drug Eluting
      Balloon (DEB) technology for the treatment of the Superficial Femoral Artery (SFA) ischemic
      obstructive  vascular disease in patients presenting with long lesions. As secondary aim
      this study is going to explore treatment effect on a number of procedural and clinical
      endpoints in order to collect information to design a future comparative effectiveness
      study.

clinical_study.brief_title: Drug Eluting Balloon (DEB) and Long Lesions of Superficial Femoral Artery (SFA) Ischemic Vascular Disease

detailed_description.textblock:
The study is aimed at collecting preliminary safety and efficacy data related to the use of
      Drug Eluting Balloon (DEB) technology for the treatment of symptomatic Superficial Femoral
      Artery (SFA) ischemic vascular disease in patients presenting with long lesions.

      The present clinical evaluation is intended as a prospective observational data collection
      of patient treatment in full accordance with institution standard practice and utilizing an
      approved (CE marked) DEB currently available on the market.

study_pop.textblock:
Patients affected by lower extremities artery disease (LEAD) and referred to the
        participating centres for the endovascular treatment of de novo or restenotic lesions (no
        in stent restenosis) in the superficial femoral and proximal popliteal arteries will be
        considered for the study

facility.name: Maria Eleonora Hospital, GVM Care & Research

clinical_study.official_title: Safety and Efficacy of the Drug Eluting Balloon (DEB) for the Treatment of the Superficial Femoral Artery (SFA) Ischemic Vascular Disease in Symptomatic Patients Presenting With Long Lesions: a Pilot Study

other_outcome.description: the rate of instrumental restenosis as determined by duplex ultrasound Peak Systolic Velocity Ratio (PSVR) ≤ 2.4 post-index procedure  and the rate of instrumental restenosis as determined by duplex ultrasound Peak Systolic Velocity Ratio (PSVR) ≤2 and ≤3.5 at 12 months (6, and 24 if available) or at unscheduled visit, as evaluated by an independent core lab
other_outcome.time_frame: within the first 24 months after percutaneous treatment

other_outcome.description: rate of procedural success i.e. complete revascularization in the absence of peri-procedural complications
other_outcome.time_frame: at the end of percutaneous treatment

other_outcome.description: walking capacity as assessed by walking impairment questionnaire (WIQ) and quality of life (EQ5D questionnaire) at 6, 12 and 24 months post-procedure vs. baseline
other_outcome.measure: walking capacity and quality of life
other_outcome.time_frame: whithin 6, 12 and 24 months post-procedure vs. baseline

overall_official.affiliation: Maria Eleonora Hospital, GVM Care & Research

primary_outcome.description: Primary patency is defined as freedom from the combined endpoints of clinically-driven target lesion revascularization (TLR) and >50% restenosis in the treated lesion. Clinically driven TLR is defined as any re-intervention within the target lesion due to symptoms or drop of ABI of ≥20% or >0.15 when compared to post-procedure. Restenosis > 50% is defined by a peak systolic velocity ratio (PSVR) > 2.4.
primary_outcome.time_frame: within the first 12 months after percutaneous treatment

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: evaluate the incidence of the composite of all Major Adverse Events (MAE) through 24 months i.e. the first occurrence of any of the following: death from any cause, major target limb amputation, thrombosis at the target lesion site
secondary_outcome.measure: composite of all Major Adverse Events (MAE)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within the first 24 months after percutaneous treatment

secondary_outcome.description: to assess the incidence of Major Adverse Cardiac and Cerebrovascular event (MACCE) individual components through 24 months
secondary_outcome.measure: incidence of Major Adverse Cardiac and Cerebrovascular event (MACCE)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: within the first 24 months after percutaneous treatment

secondary_outcome.description: compare clinical improvement as assessed by Rutherford Class changes at 6, 12 and 24 months with respect to baseline
secondary_outcome.measure: clinical improvement as assessed by Rutherford Class changes

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Prospective
